Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Amazon in December 2016.
Interview Description: Recruiter found me and I just applied to their Annapurna labs. 1nd round phone screen is from the team, he asked about OS related question includes multithreaded, synchronization, and some simple coding exercise with some system performance related follow up. It was interesting. However, 2nd Phone interview they assigned a guy from AWS and I felt this is so unprofessional. The question is some resource allocator which allocate instances for task with resource requirement . First, they use Java, which I'm not very familiar with. Second, the input is not very clear and is very misleading. There was no sample input and output either. In the first 30 min, I was just trying to figure out how the question is like. And next 10 min I present a solution and interviewer said its not he wants because the resource cannot be separated into 2 instances, which He didn't tell me before. Then next few minutes I just noticed that the question is very hard then he admitted, the real solution is very very hard. Then he explained that the question is more complex version of knapsack problem. Finally I realized that he just wants something works but not necessarily the best solution. I asked him why he asked the question and he said it was closed to something they faced before. There is so much I can complain. First, expecting people to figure out and answer such question in less than 1 hour? Second, he didn't even check your resume, while I clearly write my most comfortable language is C/C++. Third, no concrete input/output in the beginning? That is VERY professional. Fourth, since I applied for embedded engineering/ OS / hardware, software integration, I don't feel the question is much related. I understand the interviewer wanted to come up something interesting but it just turned out to be a mess. I will say among all the interviews in my career, this is definitely the worst! It just wastes my time!
Interview Questions: some resource allocator which allocate instances for task with resource requirement   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at Amazon (Gdańsk (Poland)) in April 2017.
Interview Description: Telephone interview for about 75 minutes about behavioral and technical aspects of Computer Science, like data structures and how to implement some functionalities. They also asked me some questions about some personal decisions that I had to take in the past when facing a dilemma.
Interview Questions: What was your decision when you had to face a dilemma to use a technology or gather information to use another technology.   1 Answer

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3+ months. I interviewed at Amazon (Berlin (Germany)) in February 2017.
Interview Description: I was contacted by Amazon recruiter, she asked me to send over my CV as they were having an event in Berlin.She sent me a link to an online test, i'd say the test was average , 2 problems to solve in 1 hour then a survey to check the personality for 15 mins.I passed the test then i got a call from the recruiter, it was a phone interview for about ( 30 mins ), she asked general data structure and algorithms questions .After that i was asked to select a time slot at the hiring event, the hiring event lasted for 4 days and i had to select one day to have ( 4 hours ) interviews.The recruiter sent me over a punch of materials to prepare my self for the interview.At the hiring event, i was interviewed by ( 4 ) Amazon employees, they were mostly really experienced employees brought from Seattle to Berlin just for the hiring event. The interview topics were mainly about : 1- System design 2- OOP 3- Algorithms 4- Data Structureseach interview consisted of 2 parts ( personal experience - technical questions ).the interviews were above average and i can say even difficult.After a couple of days i got an email from the recruiter saying ( Congratulations offer extended )so i passed the interviews and i was waiting for the offer, she asked me for free time slot to make a call with me and give the offer, i gave her "a lot of time slots", nevertheless she kept stalling me for "3 weeks"!! pretending that she must arrange a free time with another recruiter in Berlin in order to make the call.Lastly i sent her an email informing her that i'll be on vacation for 2 weeks and i'd be unavailable during it. So she scheduled a call with me the day before my vacation.Then she called me at 21:30 and said : "We are sorry we can't offer you a position currently since we are doing restructuring and we are in hiring freeze !!!!!!!!" , i asked about the timeline for this restructuring then she said "maybe more than a year !!!!!!!".I was totally shocked, Amazon has just wasted 3 months of my life between preparing, tests, interviews and waiting for phone calls.I sent an email to my recruiter and to the recruiting manager in Berlin asking for the real reason behind this, since it makes no sense that Amazon would make such a huge hiring event and bring tens of people from Seattle just to stop the process after 10 days ?? But of course no one replied to my questions.As of my opinion i think the real reason was my nationality, the recruiter didn't notice that i'm from an embargoed country till she wanted to write an offer.But anyway regardless of the reason, this was the most unprofessional thing i've ever encountered till now.
Interview Questions: Highly abstract and generic OOP question   3 Answers

Application: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Amazon in March 2017.
Interview Description: I was emailed an online assessment to complete - this was pretty easy, required basic programming and logic knowledge. A week later, I was emailed a second online assessment for two coding questions. These were harder, but I still was able to get my solutions to pass all but one test case. I was sent a rejection email a week and a half later. Not sure why. I didn't like the lack of human contact during this whole process - it would have been a lot more engaging if I were able to speak to a live human. I'll admit taking online exams is a little less intimidating than in person interviews, but I was also a little freaked out by the third party they were using to administer the test. They track everything you do - eye movement, browser size, webcam, microphone, everything. Understandable to prevent cheating but it was still a little uncomfortable.

Application: I applied online. The process took 4+ weeks. I interviewed at Amazon (Milan (Italy)) in December 2017.
Interview Description: The whole process is made by three steps: the first screening (a call) with a recruiter, then a coding test, and then the "whiteboard" interview. The first call is composed by very general questions and superficial technical questions; nothing special here, basically yourself in a coffee shop. The second phase, the coding test, is 90 minutes with 2 questions covering basic data structures (queue, tree). The third phase is pretty cool, a half-day interview with 4 different engineer/managers chatting with you about your professional experience; here they will ask you to "draw" (design) systems. I failed, but it was a pretty nice experience.
Interview Questions: Design the (Amazon) system to send the confirmation of a purchase made. You have the information about the items that were bought and the information (e.g, email address) of the user the bought the items.   Answer Question

It was very similar to the ones you see on Hackerrank. There were two questions. The first one was very easy, the second was quite complicated IIRC.

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at Amazon (Indore (India)) in January 2016.

Application: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Amazon (Chennai (India)) in January 2018.
Interview Description: My friend referred my CV, and it got selected. Got the call to schedule the phone interview in next three days. I scheduled it to next week so that I get some time to prepare.Phone interview went for around 40 min, and it was simple. The first round was coding round, where it lasted for around 40 min. It was an 1:1 interview, where the interviewer asked me write codes for the given questions using a preferred language (I chose C). I tried writing, but couldn't solve 50% of the problems he had asked, so got rejected.
Interview Questions: Given a number N. how can you find the closest Palindrome number whose absolute difference with given number is minimum?   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Amazon (London, England (UK)) in March 2018.
Interview Description: I've applied online and whole process took ~2 weeks.The interview process is composed from 3 steps:- 1st step: 90 minute online assessment. You have to finish 2 (easy-medium) algorithmic problems in 1,5 hours.- 2nd step: Telephone Interview (Competency/Technical Based) 1 hour- 3rd Step: In-house Interviews (Competency/ Technical Based), 1 hour each, typically organized over a half or full day.I've failed 2nd step. As usual they did not provide any feedback. At this step they've asked me to implement a simple LRU cache list and also some "Amazon Leadership" behavior questions. I think, because of those questions they've declined me, so do not underestimate them.
Interview Questions: Design and implement a data structure for Least Recently Used (LRU) cache. It should support the following operations: get and put.get(key) - Get the value (will always be positive) of the key if the key exists in the cache, otherwise return -1.put(key, value) - Set or insert the value if the key is not already present. When the cache reached its capacity, it should invalidate the least recently used item before inserting a new item.Follow up:Could you do both operations in O(1) time complexity?   Answer Question

Application: I applied through other source. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Amazon (Berlin (Germany)) in July 2014.
Interview Description: First pre-screen telephone interview was with the team lead of the team I would be joining. We had a discussion about various topics, experience, desires and motivations. This was finished off with a review of the corporate values by which point I knew the job was not for me.
Interview Questions: What is my experience with the technology they use?   Answer Question

Application: I applied through college or university. The process took 8 weeks. I interviewed at Amazon (Cambridge, East of England, England (UK)) in January 2018.
Interview Description: Overall very positive and professional experience. The process consisted of a telephone interview covering a basic programming problem (hackerrank style). I was then invited for an onsite interview which consisted of a number of technical interviews, again hackerrank medium style questions algorithmic questions and also one on object oriented design. The interviewers were helpful and very positive in general. I would advise future applicants to really spend a decent amount of time going over behavioural questions which were a big part of the process. Think talking about previous team experiences, difficulties, how you handled situations etc. Also they are very big on the amazon leadership principles so definitely read up on them too.
Interview Questions: Various hackerrank stye questionsMany background behavioural questions   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at Amazon (London, England (UK)) in December 2017.
Interview Description: I applied to Amazon numerous times before. Usually they used to turn me down with a Hackerrank or similar test, I'm not very good at those. This time I had a somewhat classic interview, starting with a recruiter calling me, followed by a technical phone screen. Both went quite well, so after weeks of delay, I was invited to an on-site round. This was the point where the awkward things started out.I was very busy that time, and also it turned out my travel documents were expired. The recruiter was pushing me aggressively to travel to London the next Friday, since they had a hiring event there that time. I just refused to go, I explained her even if I had free time for that, I had had to renew my passport anyways. I had to submit a scan of my expired passport to the recruiter to make her believe my story (yes, she explicitly asked for it). So we scheduled the interview for a week later finally.The next week I flew out to London. I asked my recruiter if I can expense the taxi or uber from and to the airport. She referred to their principle of frugality, and advised to use public transport. I was wondering what can I expect from this company at that point. Anyways I arrived to the hotel.The interview day was quite good. I had 5-6 interviews. At Amazon each interview is partly technical and partly managerial. The technical part is quite standard (whiteboard coding). The managerial part can be quite annoying after the 3rd round. Basically they test you against their so-called leadership principles, ask you to tell about certain situations you had on the job before, or decisions you made or would make. These leadership principles are some kind of religious Amazon mantra they keep repeating during the interviews, if you ask me it's a bit scary. Anyways my overall experience regarding the on-site interviews were quite good. I met really smart and competent engineers, as well as managers, so even though there were some red flags, I still considered Amazon a possibility.The next week the recruiter let me know that the feedback was very positive on my interviews and they'd like to find me a team, because the team I was originally interviewing to was already full. After some additional introductory phone calls, I picked a team working on cutting edge AI stuff in Cambridge. Everyone I spoke to in the Cambridge office was extremely nice, but still, I was worried, because the overall engineer feedback on Amazon is at least very mixed. I asked them to wait with the offer because I was also interviewing with other major companies.Their offer was reasonable, but nothing extraordinary. I decided to sign with an other top company for significantly better salary, perks, and location, but a bit less interesting project. I really loved the team at Amazon Cambridge, so I wrote the recruiter a rather long feedback explaining my decision, and suggesting to keep in touch. The most disappointing thing in the entire process was that I got absolutely no answer, farewell notes, or anything for that. I never heard back from them. These little negative things will keep me far away from Amazon anyways.
Interview Questions: NAN

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at Amazon.
Interview Description: I just finished my Amazon Front End Intern Interview, here is the process. The interview took about 1 hour, and it’s a phone interview with code sharing website Collabedit199. It’s my first technical interview ever. :laughing: And the interview happened in China, I am interviewed by a guy in Beijing.I was notified a day before the interview, the recruiter called me, and then an email about the detail of the interview was sent. And I started to search some resources for the last minute preparation. Here is some great links I found:This site444 is very helpful in presented you some interview question together with answer and possible follow-up question from the interviewer. And by searching the Github you will find some other resources such as this one164. But it doesn’t seem to provide the answer, so it’s relatively less helpful.During the interview, the interviewer was very quiet, and he just didn’t provide much useful feedback when I try to explain something to him, so I have no idea whether he understand it or not. It’s especially true when I am trying to explain the idea behind the Quick Sort algorithm. I have been speaking for about 10 minutes without any feedback from him, dead silent on the other side of the phone. And I had to ask “whether I make myself clear?”. And he replied with something like ‘I understand’ or ‘keep writing the code’.
Interview Questions: What is the difference between strict mode and normal mode?   Answer Question

One thing I enjoyed about Amazon’s interview process was the rate at which they moved you through the process. I always heard back with updates on next steps within a few days. Experience will vary, but I have experience with a number of companies where the recruiters take a while to respond or sometimes forget to respond altogether.

Application: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Amazon (Tokyo (Japan)).
Interview Description: HR was really professional along the way. I had only one interview of 1h on the phone. They asked me to code the solution to one problem and then went through my CV while asking questions. I found the solution but I guess the stress of the interview prevented me from answering fast enough or with the quality they expected.Even though I failed I think it was a good learning experience. I just wish they would provide a feedback on why the test was failed; for personal improvement. Right now I don't know what I should improve. My coding skills? My softskills or interview skills? My last point would be that during such interviews the interviewer should ask at least 2 questions. One problem only does not provide a good sampling of the candidate solving skills, especially in a stressful context.
Interview Questions: They asked me about projects I contributed to that were relevant to the position I was applying to.   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Amazon.

However, the technical test was tricky and also very strict about copy paste. It does not allow even copying from your own code inside assessment.

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at Amazon.
Interview Description: Psychometric online test followed by online coding test then phone interview. The psychometric is nothing unexpected and just logic questions and pattern matching etc, the coding test was quite difficult given time constraints and consisted of 2 questions in about an hour.
Interview Questions: Find the total waiting time of connections to a server on a round-robin scheduler system   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at Amazon (London, England (UK)).
Interview Description: Extremely disappointed and unprofessional.The recruiters approached me and scheduled me for a second call with a different recruiter, but he forgot and wasted my time. I emailed them and rescheduled, but guess what, he forgot again. The third time he called me, from his car. I played along because it was Amazon and got a Hackerrank challenge. I cleared that one and got my phone technical interview.The engineer was very professional and the interview went great, the problem was to count Islands in a grid, easily solvable with a BFS to find connected components in a graph.I got a date for the onsite interview, the recruiters said it was not technical and that I would not need to write any code. That sounded wrong to me so I prepared for the technical interview as recommended online. And I was right, I had to write code. The recruiter did not warned me that the interview's main focus was on systems design (scalability, load balancing, software architecture and databases) which I studied but not in depth.The engineers were great, the problems were interesting, one of them required me to implement the topological sort on a DAG.A week later I was told the engineers were happy with my interviews but not for software engineer 2, so they wanted me to join as software engineer 1 level. I did not even know I was interviewing for SE2, another massive error from the recruiters.They presented the offer to me, we negotiated salaries and we agreed on a pretty decent deal,but in the last minute, literally before signing, they withdrew the offer. The explanation was that they had made a mistake and the position they were offering me was only available for graduates so I did not qualified.Overall the process took almost two months, I had to book days off to attend the staggering 8 interviews, just to be accepted and then rejected for a stupid and discriminatory reason. Who cares how old are you if you can do the job, I'm 29 by the way. My advise, forget Amazon, apply for Google.
Interview Questions: Given a bi dimensional array of 1-land and 0-sea write a method that returns the number of islands. Two cells are connected if they share an edge of the grid.   1 Answer

Application: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Amazon.
Interview Description: The company had visited the college for recruitment purpose.There were 5 rounds conducted in total.Initial round comprised of coding test which had 2 coding question and 20 MCQs. After the first round students were shortlisted for further face to face interview rounds.
Interview Questions: check for BST   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Amazon (Winnipeg, MB (Canada)) in March 2018.
Interview Description: This was an almost entire day technical interview. This was not in Seattle or Vancouver, so a few interviews were remote, but still I had to write solutions on a white board.This was not very different from what is described in the Cracking the Code Interview book. Lots of focus on Big O notation and scalability. I had a couple interviews in the morning, then one of the guys took me out for lunch and three more in the afternoon. Data structure and Big O notation are the big focus, while you design solutions on paper, white board, or plain text editor. Each interviewer has a different preference. Lots of behavioural questions, but also the expected things. Basically they ask you about the most challenging situations and how you handled them, like when your vote on a solution was overruled, or when you had to throw away a lot of code and start from scratch again.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you thought you had a better solution but you had to implement it differently.   Answer Question

Application: NAN
Interview Description: Was very good. I enjoyed the interview a lot , the question dey asked were based on real life and application type and i solved them easily with their help

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4+ weeks. I interviewed at Amazon (Buenos Aires (Argentina)) in October 2017.

Application: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Amazon (London, England (UK)) in November 2018.
Interview Description: It's the most exhausting interviews I have ever had. Every round consists of 20 minutes behaviour questions which you have to keep in mind the Amazon Principles all the time, plus a 20 minutes leetcode medium / design session. After answering those behaviour questions you feel like you don't have energy to do the technical part and there are five rounds for onsite. I can still remember they asked me Integer to Roman, which the interviewer himself was not even very clear with the requirements. Generally speaking it's a bad experience because they don't respect candidates. When they want you, you will get updated quickly, otherwise they don't bother to send you an email. Their interviews will tell you their culture is not flexible and work extremely hard anyway. One thing to remember, keep going to Gym for half an year before go to Amazon onsite interview, or if you want to have a better life, never try to think about working for Amazon.
Interview Questions: Integer to Roman.   1 Answer

English pronunciation was poor too, really hard to understand the questions sometimes.Coding task was Fibonacci series, i have done it very well along with test cases and answer her questions, however i do not know why i was rejected ?Contacted HR and got a reply that "As per company policy We do not disclose".

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at Amazon (Cape Town (South Africa)).
Interview Description: Long process.. they generally do a 3 phase process:Phase1 starts with a telephone technical screen on basic 2nd year computer science questions.Phase2 is sold as an HR interview which is more of a discussion on experience and workplace behavioural assessment but if they do not actually want to hire you, in Cpt they basically ask you the questions you struggled with in Phase1 and expand on it. You will notice on review that this sneaky way of weeding people out is done selectively.Phase3 is onsite / i did not do this.Overall I was not impressed with the misdirection as I prepare for interviews.
Interview Questions: What is the Big O notation of various algorithms, explain how various tree structures work and the efficiency there of e.g. AVL, red black trees, explain sorting methods and why or when to use each, explain how you would troubleshoot a problem where the internet is not working, explain dis/advantages of recursive solutions vs threads and the limitations there of, explain how your internet query is handled from your browser all the way to the host .. how does this differ with CDM networks.   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Amazon (Dublin, Co. Dublin (Ireland)).
Interview Description: Applied online, got an email the same day about an online assessment after completing it I remove my application for the position.They outlined two sections in their email, one coding and the other logical reasoning. Coding sections was 7 questions each one was literally one line of code to change to get the program working. The problems ranged from wrong condition statements, assignment of variables, and loop corrections. Any second year cs college student could pass. The second assessment was a logical reasoning questions 24 questions 35 mins to complete. Straight forward questions to complete. The questions are basically the same as those in primary school assessments. One question in this section is the same as those asked in no mans sky to receive coordinates from bases. Because of how the screening assessment could be summaries I removed myself from the process. It was going to be a waste of both my time and any hr persons.Two points of worrier from the application process and the screening, is that I have only ever been asked to disclose my date of birth when applying for this role. The second was the logical reasoning section could discriminate against those with a form of dyslexia as some of the logical reasoning questions do get more worded towards the end of the section and also don't test for a persons logical reasoning in a software development way.
Interview Questions: Simple condition statement fixes, loops and variable assignment   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at Amazon.
Interview Description: Unfortunately this was the worst interviewing experience I ever had. I applied online and was contacted by a recruiter to set up a phone interview directly. I provided my availability but the response was very slow. Finally, an interview was set up. The interviewer was actually very nice and it was an awesome interview. I received an email that I was selected for the final onsite round and that the interview will be scheduled soon. The days passed and I was always assured that they are right now scheduling it and I will receive the confirmation soon. After asking several times (and several confirmations) I was finally told that they already found somebody else. I think it is ok not to be the first choice, but it is not ok to provide plain lies and make me keeping the date free.
Interview Questions: Simple algorithm and behavioral questions   Answer Question

Application: I applied online. The process took 2+ weeks. I interviewed at Amazon (Asti (Italy)) in January 2019.
Interview Description: Everything started with a very easy online test. They give you plenty of time (2 hours).An online interview (using Amazon Chime) has followed few days after.Finally an in-person 5 hours long interview interview (started at 12.00 and ended at 18.00, with 1 hour lunch break) with 5 different people (one remote from Seattle).In the end, I sent them the expense form, with the 750KM roundtrip traveling, and they capped the roundtrip at 500KM: they invited me and then decided I was too far to have a complete refund for the expenses. Had to write them many time to have an answer and an explanation,
Interview Questions: They asked me about my previous experiences, how I solved issues, how I reacted to failures and how I applied Amazon principles to the challenges that I've been faced to.   1 Answer

Application: I applied online. I interviewed at Amazon.

Application: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at Amazon.
Interview Description: I've participated of the recruiting event Amazon did in Buenos Aires (Argentina) - Apr/2019. The selection process have three phases: first an online test, then a phone interview and after that the interviews in person. The first phase (online test) had two problem solving exercises, similar to hacker rank style. After solving the exercises it is also required to explain your thoughts about the solution.The second phase was a phone interview where I had to talk about my experience, answer behavioral and technical questions, and solve a development problem after the talk (they use a tool similar do google docs so you can code and they can see what you are doing). I didn't passed from the second phase.During all the process the recruiter was helpful and I they never took more than one or two days to get back with an update.
Interview Questions: First question (online test) - Array iteration/sort   Answer Question

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at Amazon (São Paulo, São Paulo (Brazil)).

Os assuntos abordados pelos entrevistadores são pertinentes, no entanto. Há bastante foco em aspéctos teóricos de ciência da computação, bem como em abordagens práticas para soluções de problemas reais.

Application: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Amazon.
Interview Description: Fui levado ao Chile para uma série de 4 entrevistas para uma vaga em Seattle nos EUA. Fui muito bem tratado, todo os procedimentos de viagem e hospedagem foram custeados pela Amazon mediante reembolso (parte ruim, demorou pra pagar). Mas é um processo bem custoso em termos de conhecimento. Exigem conhecimentos bem aprofundados (ainda que não necessários as vagas). Achei também que desconsideram um pouco suas experiencias anteriores, focando apenas em possíveis problemas na Amazon. Foram poucas perguntas sobre problemas que eu tinha resolvido ou situações de outras empresas.
Interview Questions: As perguntas das 4 entrevistas foram de situações hipotéticas de modelagem de aplicações, estruturas de dados (bem profundo).   1 Answer
